cards.name: The Fool
cards.meaning_up: An awakening. A return to the self, to the true nature of your own being. Proceeding forward from a true, open heart. A new journey, one taken without baggage or carrying issues from the past. A new beginning that can occur at any time in your life, as long as the past and future are not feared, and you can be fully in the present moment. The clock – just past noon or midnight, the start of a new cycle – is intertwined with the compass, intertwined with the spider’s web, showing there are many paths to take. The egg cracking open from the blossoming flower, and the emerging worm, are signs of new life, fresh eyes, a new morning, a new perspective. The need to start over with a fresh and clean slate. Taking a risk. Finding your way. Having faith in yourself. Proceeding into the unknown with only your innermost feelings driving you. Trust.

cards.name: The Magician
cards.meaning_up: The alchemist. The individual. The spark of creation. The Magician shows your potential, your ability to manifest, your active nature. Assertion of the self, acknowledgement of your own power. The alchemy of the Magician blends spiritual sources – as shown by the pyramids, symbolizing the ancient search for connection to the divine – and physical resources – shown by the magical tools on the metaphysical tables. The human sits between them, the active agent that brings the two together. An urging to take action, to move forward using all your gifts.

cards.name: The High Priestess
cards.meaning_up: Inner wisdom. Becoming enlightened from within. The knowledge, the secrets and the magic that you carry in your body and soul from generations of ancestors, your intuitive nature. Clairvoyance, being receptive. The mystical nature of this card is shown through the impossible – a spider’s web woven between fingers, a snake conjoined with a chain. Isis, the Egyptian goddess, is shown with her bird of knowledge and symbol of the moon cycles, keys to the hidden kingdom of the divine. Reflection, a mirror, a time of stillness or austerity, spiritual knowledge. Connection to the inner self. Needing to retreat within, solitude. Following your gut feelings or your third eye. Quietness.

cards.name: The Empress
cards.meaning_up: Abundance. Fertility. An accumulation of energy. The feminine. A naked woman lies at ease among bountiful flora and fauna. The natural cycles of growth. Inherent gifts. The act of creation. An endless well of love and creativity. Working in line with the world so that you manifest blessings. Recognizing your power. Nurturing what you love. The fullness of being. Comfort in your body and surroundings. Taking advantage of opportunities that come your way. Giving and receiving love.

cards.name: The Emperor
cards.meaning_up: Control. Structure, responsibility, the way of the world. A need to create more boundaries or to break away from limitations. An authority in your life. Foundation. The institutions that shape the way you live: the job you go to every day, the school you attend, your neighborhood, and your community. These can act as either support or confinement. Understanding structure as a tool rather than law. Finding a solid base so that you can take action from a secure place. Making sense of the world. Various shapes and structures are stacked in a row, showing how balance is needed between organically recognizing forms to create safety out of chaos, and imposing rule in an attempt to control. Seeing where adhering to others’ ideals works and where it doesn’t work for you. Finding autonomy.

cards.name: The Hierophant
cards.meaning_up: A mediator between two worlds. Seeking a mentor, a guide. Someone who can provide teachings and lessons, contexts for the events of life, a key to understanding more. Ways that you find meaning in your life. Positive connection within your community. A safe place to connect with your spiritual teachers. The Hierophant seeks to reach down and pull others up, to benefit the whole community. Using knowledge and experience to empower others. Setting an example. Being a role model. The snakes wrapped around the hands represent the wide search for self-knowledge, reading lines on a hand, accepting secret wisdom from a snake. The keys, the open eyes, the yin-yang third eye, all speak about the unlocking of truth, the clarity of spiritual connection.

cards.name: The Lovers
cards.meaning_up: Union, harmony. Merging of two. Restoration. Ecstasy. Complementary energies. Physical connection. Love, sexuality, happiness. Recognizing how opposites can fit together and work together. Intimacy with another, intimacy with all parts of yourself. Finding balance in the opposing qualities within yourself. Light and dark, active and passive, inner and outer. Seeing both sides of a situation and finding your place somewhere along the spectrum, making choices and setting priorities. Valuing yourself and others. Meeting your match. The male and female personas are merged into one being, the playing card king and queen integrated into one entity. The rows of yin-yangs and the sun and moon show balance between opposing forces. Differences resolved for a greater purpose. Finding a solution. Acting from love.

cards.name: The Chariot
cards.meaning_up: Ambition. Will. The drive to succeed. Presenting yourself in a good light. Doing whatever it takes. Summoning the strength. Empowerment. Achievement within the structures of your life. Reaching your goal. Promotion, elevation, fame. The chain and the leaves surround a brick wall, the things we have to work with, the limitations of society and the natural laws that dictate the boundaries of life. Inside though, there are possibilities for expansion of the self. Two snakes, as always a reminder of evolution and transformation, with their ability to shed their skin as they grow larger than it, contort their bodies into fantastic shapes. The top hat, cane and stars, symbols of power, success, reaching ever greater heights, striving to be the best. Focused and directed energy.

cards.name: Strength
cards.meaning_up: Courage. Grace. Developing a relationship over time. Having a gentle approach. An intangible process. Working towards perfection. Domesticating, taming and integrating the wild. Not forcing or pushing an issue. The wild panther is surrounding by hands offering flowers and breaking its chains. Calming down, defusing a situation through kindness and generosity, not domination. Winning someone over. Loving your enemies, embracing your weaknesses, overcoming a problem through care and sweetness. Extending a loving gesture in a time of chaos or conflict. Being the bigger person. Responding to anger or fear with integrity, not reacting.

cards.name: The Hermit
cards.meaning_up: Experience, wisdom, enlightenment. Integrating all types of knowledge into a cohesive set of beliefs. Open to different philosophies. Travelling outside of your comfort zone, venturing out on your own. Forging your own path. Silence and solitude.  Retreat into the world of books and study. Gathering information to form understanding. Natural guidance and teachings. The owl, a symbol of wisdom as well as nocturnal time, is surrounded by the constellations of the zodiac signs. The links of the chains he rests on are the connections he makes, using past experiences to shape a world-view that supports current action. Relating to a bigger picture, looking outside of yourself for perspective, and inside for truth. Getting wiser.

cards.name: Wheel Of Fortune
cards.meaning_up: Destiny. Serendipity. Chance, coincidences, luck. The mystical nature of how events interlock and influence and affect each other. The inter-connectedness of the world. The changing nature of the cycles of life. Engaging in the dance of life. Following a winding path. Allowing for the strange timing of the universe. Fate. The repeating circles have an endless quality, a chain of snakes encircles a row of comedy and tragedy masks, encircling a row of spider webs, encircling a jumble of numbers from a clock face. Constant alteration of what you think you know to be true.

cards.name: Justice
cards.meaning_up: Cause and effect. Being aware of right and wrong. Anything legal. Setting into stone. Your actions having real consequences. Moral ethics and values. Taking all aspect into consideration. The beauty in right action. Doing the right thing. The law of karma. The most iconic symbol of Justice is the scales, the need to have balance. The scales shown are reminiscent of Egyptian iconography, referring to the weighing of a person’s heart against a feather, in the hopes that it is as light and free. Not having any blemishes on your conscious. Needing to right a wrong. The symbol of the rose with the book unites the practice of law and ethics with the practice of love and generosity towards all. Fairness. Equality.

cards.name: The Hanged Man
cards.meaning_up: Being in transition. Held in place. Your circumstances have not caught up to your inner evolution. Feeling stuck, no movement or traction, apparent inactivity. Turning your gaze inward to find that things are on pause so you can align from the inside out. The key at the moment is to unlock something inside, not outside. Expansion of mind. The rose tethered to the spider web shows us a place where the only limits are in our thoughts, and therefore they can be expanded. The butterflies refer to transformation, to re-configuration, to growth. Learning how to integrate a mystical practice, a connection to the mysterious self, in the real world. Getting more in touch with yourself, learning to proceed from inner cues rather than outer ones. Seeking enlightenment.

cards.name: Death
cards.meaning_up: Change. Rebirth. An ending brings a new beginning. A sign of the natural cycles of life. Life carries Death within it and Death carries Life within it. One does not exist without the other. Acceptance. Balancing light and dark. The Grim Reaper, a traditional figure of death, is shown within jungle leaves and flying butterflies, reminding us that growth sometimes requires loss, that change is inevitable, and that even while things change shape and form, there are always constants. It calls for you to drop your resistance. To flow instead of struggle. To let go of control. To release. To see an open door wherever another is closing. To accept change as natural and necessary.

cards.name: Temperance
cards.meaning_up: Moderation, patience. Seeing all things as flowing. Allowance. A spiritual practice that finds order in chaos. Balance. A Zen attitude. Meditation. Two hands carefully balance two vessels, spilling a few water drops. A statue and a two-headed snake represent eternity, continuation. Finding structures that support grace and stillness, giving things the time they need. Calmness. Healing.

cards.name: The Devil
cards.meaning_up: Obsession, addiction. Bound to unhealthy relationships, desires, and cravings. In chains, enslaved, not free. A connection needs to be severed to allow personal movement again. Tied down, tied to someone or something. Karmically under contract. A master dynamic, holding power. Abuse. Toxic connections. The seduction of self-destruction. Momentary pleasure at the expense of long-lasting contentment. A rejection of beneficial values due to the ego being stronger than the soul. Entrapment by your own choice, but there is always a choice there. Two hands are handcuffed to each other, and entwined with a snake. Snake Eyes dice show a losing bet. Sometimes: pleasure, motivation or will, shaking things up.

cards.name: The Tower
cards.meaning_up: Trauma, destruction, disruption. The Tower marks an event with a Before and an After. Everything changes. Return is impossible. The foundation crumbles, the rug is pulled out from under your feet. Total loss. The three moments of breaking apart – the columns crashing down, the 6 of hearts card ripped in half, the broken chain –  speak to loss, separation, mourning, grief. But the broken chain also references freedom, and the opportunity to find meaning elsewhere once recovery is found. Breaking free from the ego. The traumatic moment of the Tower points to a moment where the separation of the self from the soul is acutely felt. How you proceed from this is a chance to build stronger links, a greater sense of self, a more holistic experience of life.

cards.name: The Star
cards.meaning_up: Positivity. Embodying a high vibrational energy. Letting your light shine. Acting from your gifts and talents. Sharing yourself with others. Simply being. The Egyptian sky goddess Nut is shown arcing over the natural worlds of the earth and sea, shown by the birds and fish, while she contains the qualities of fire and air, the stars in the sky. Uniting all the elements within yourself – the emotional nature of water, the groundedness of earth, the activity of fire, the ethereality of air. Aligned within yourself and with the external world. Replenishing yourself so that you can continue to give to others. Pulling deeply from within and offering to others. Self-care, self-respect, self-esteem. Nurturing yourself, and in turn nurturing others.

cards.name: The Moon
cards.meaning_up: Mystery. Tricky by nature. The moon does not shine its own light, instead it reflects the light of the sun. A mask, showing where information is obscured, possibly manipulated, intentionally confusing, misleading, and unclear. But also information that is secret for another reason– esoteric knowledge, magical thinking, psychic ability, the tides, and memory. Hidden deep within all of us is both ancient animal instinct and ancient human wisdom. Can be a sign of addiction or deception. The wolf shown has both a wild nature and a magical one, as he balances the crescent moon. The dual nature of the moon – the shadow side, the darkness, and also the source of feminine, receptive empowerment – is shown in the two masks of the Joker card. The checkerboard circle and the snake in the shape of the infinity symbol point to the looping nature of understanding, the endless layers of meaning inherent in existence.

cards.name: The Sun
cards.meaning_up: Finding your path in life. Energy, vitality. Truth. Honesty. Confidence. Realizing your dreams. Being in your true nature. Recharging your batteries. Directness. Happiness. Leopards frolic with flowers raining down, under an energized, radiant sun. Wild cats embody the sun’s playfulness and daring. Self-awareness. Self-knowledge allows you to be charismatic, to feel self-possessed, to act authentically. Enlightening, encouraging, clarifying light. Loyalty. Integrity.

cards.name: Judgement
cards.meaning_up: Shedding of the ego to reach the soul. Things as they really are becoming clear to you. Clarity about what’s important. Letting a new self emerge. Three Tibetan Snow Lions, creatures representing eternity, freedom, and bliss, smile down on a flock of uprising birds, and a snake shedding its skin. Checkered racing flags fly above, signaling to go, move forward. All of the energy is about ascension, progression, evolution. Release from karmic contracts. Birthing a new self. Witnessing change in yourself. Reinvigorating yourself so you can move on to the next level. Release of blockages, fears and insecurities. Connection and merging with the higher self.

cards.name: The World
cards.meaning_up: Opening up to the universe. Freedom. At one with all. Inner peace. Learning the secrets of the world. An ouroboro, snake eating its tail, encircles a chain containing a spider web. All is interconnected, all is linked, all is continuous. Surrounding it are the playing cards of all four suits, the four elements – air, fire, water, earth. A rising sun, growing plants. The spider refers to an iconic creation myth of the spider spinning the world into existence, a manifestation of thoughts and intentions. Being an active participant in your own daily creation of the world. Everything is available to you. Say yes.

cards.name: Page of Wands
cards.meaning_up: A hand holds a royal flush. Recognizing your skills and gifts, and using them wisely – or accepting help from someone else’s skills and gifts. A good thing coming into your life, good news. An aspect of your life becoming more exciting. Embodying the winning energy as part of your plan to achieve your goals. Seeing, and believing, the positive.
cards.desc: In a scene similar to the former, a young man stands in the act of proclamation. He is unknown but faithful, and his tidings are strange.

cards.name: Knight of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Taking action in a daring way. Looking for excitement. Ready to take a risk. Playing with fire. Being open to miracles or serendipity. The roll of the dice and the dancing dragons show a playful energy where anything is possible.
cards.desc: He is shewn as if upon a journey, armed with a short wand, and although mailed is not on a warlike errand. He is passing mounds or pyramids. The motion of the horse is a key to the character of its rider, and suggests the precipitate mood, or things connected therewith.

cards.name: Queen of Wands
cards.meaning_up: A creative, eccentric woman. Fun, playful, warm, caring, encouraging. Her strength comes from her quickness, her embrace of the new. Giving to others, but maintains her own practices of self-care and self-exploration. Likes to laugh and enjoys herself and others. Proud, strong, and with a light inside.
cards.desc: The Wands throughout this suit are always in leaf, as it is a suit of life and animation. Emotionally and otherwise, the Queen's personality corresponds to that of the King, but is more magnetic.

cards.name: King of Wands
cards.meaning_up: An artistic man. Can be unreliable or hard to pin down, but charming and exciting to be around. Not very practical or conventional, but passionate. Can get himself into trouble through inaction, or taking the wrong action. Has a good heart but not the best instincts about himself or the people around him. Mischievous and quick-witted. Always up for a good time, but can be hiding some pain inside.
cards.desc: The physical and emotional nature to which this card is attributed is dark, ardent, lithe, animated, impassioned, noble. The King uplifts a flowering wand, and wears, like his three correspondences in the remaining suits, what is called a cap of maintenance beneath his crown. He connects with the symbol of the lion, which is emblazoned on the back of his throne.

cards.name: Ace of Wands
cards.meaning_up: A spark. An idea that pops into your head. Allowing imagination to run wild. Excitement about something just beginning. A creative energy that will grow to be much larger. Only one match is lit, but it could easily spread to the rest of the matchbook. Contagious creativity.
cards.desc: A hand issuing from a cloud grasps a stout wand or club.

cards.name: Two of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Uncertainty. Feeling overwhelmed, having many options. Open space ahead. Many possibilities, multiple paths open to you. Allowing chance to lead you. Throwing the dice allows a conversation and an interaction between you and the world around you. Seeing how what feels like many options may be narrowed down once you factor in external circumstances. Pinning down what’s really possible.
cards.desc: A tall man looks from a battlemented roof over sea and shore; he holds a globe in his right hand, while a staff in his left rests on the battlement; another is fixed in a ring. The Rose and Cross and Lily should be noticed on the left side.

cards.name: Three of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Aiming for your future. Having a dream and working towards it, even if you’re still at the starting gate. Thinking big. Allowing for growth and expansion from the outset. Being single-minded about your goals. Covering all your bases while keeping the end result in mind. The image of the hand throwing darts shows all aspects necessary for hitting your mark: Aiming true, forward momentum, hitting the bullseye.
cards.desc: A calm, stately personage, with his back turned, looking from a cliff's edge at ships passing over the sea. Three staves are planted in the ground, and he leans slightly on one of them.

cards.name: Four of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Having a good foundation. An external structure that supports emotional well-being. Joy that comes from feeling secure. The start of a house of cards has been built, a solid foundation of 4 of clubs. A bejeweled hand reaches down, satisfied with what has been built so far. Doing something that makes you happy. Work that sustains you creatively.
cards.desc: From the four great staves planted in the foreground there is a great garland suspended; two female figures uplift nosegays; at their side is a bridge over a moat, leading to an old manorial house.

cards.name: Five of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Dynamic energy that can feel chaotic, or constructive. Working with other people’s needs, making a decision to bulldoze over them or to take them into consideration. Working in a group situation with lots of opinions and desires. Group dynamics. Five hands are holding pool cues, all trying to hit their billiard balls at once. Having to figure out a cohesive way to make things work for all, or it won’t work for anyone.
cards.desc: A posse of youths, who are brandishing staves, as if in sport or strife. It is mimic warfare, and hereto correspond the

cards.name: Six of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Receiving praise and accolades from others. Feeling satisfied with your achievements but also seeing others’ satisfaction as well. Being cheered on. Support from others. Success. Being humble when winning. Including others in your triumphs. The reciprocity of the performer and the audience. A basketball shot is made under the canopy of gladiolas – a symbol of the gladiator, who performed feats of strength for the entertainment of others.
cards.desc: A laurelled horseman bears one staff adorned with a laurel crown; footmen with staves are at his side.

cards.name: Seven of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Assertion of the self. Accomplishment. Overcoming obstacles to come out on top. Sticking to your convictions. Working on achieving your goals. A cat jumps over seven burning candles, both a trick and the natural ability of a graceful animal. Being able to remain calm in a challenging situation. Grace under pressure.
cards.desc: A young man on a craggy eminence brandishing a staff; six other staves are raised towards him from below.

cards.name: Eight of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Things happening fast. Lots of action. A domino effect. Using momentum to your benefit, seeing opportunities. A row of matches burns quickly. Spreading excitement. Taking advantage of the moment. Now or never. An opportunity to bring out certain skills you have waiting in your toolbox.
cards.desc: The card represents motion through the immovable-a flight of wands through an open country; but they draw to the term of their course. That which they signify is at hand; it may be even on the threshold.

cards.name: Nine of Wands
cards.meaning_up: Dust yourself off and try again. When energy flags but there is more in reserve. Almost there. Believing in yourself despite a setback. Not allowing the past to dictate how you move forward. Waiting. Replenishing energy into a project or a mission or a belief. A breakthrough. Making it happen at the last minute. Rediscovering your passion for something that had become stale. The candle burns down but rises again once the hand re-emerges to re-light it.
cards.desc: The figure leans upon his staff and has an expectant look, as if awaiting an enemy. Behind are eight other staves--erect, in orderly disposition, like a palisade.

cards.name: Ten of Wands
cards.meaning_up: An excess of energy. Creativity let out of bounds. When your dream becomes reality but it’s too much for one person. All of the cards are shown with snakes breaking through, disrupting and keeping them from their original purpose. Excitement that clouds vision. A need to rein it in a little, or to dole out some responsibility to others.
cards.desc: A man oppressed by the weight of the ten staves which he is carrying.

cards.name: Page of Cups
cards.meaning_up: News of new love, a new child, a birth. A new attitude towards emotions and relationships, as happens when a woman becomes a mother. A positive message. A new friend that helps you out. Finding allies, finding enjoyment. A playful attitude. The excitement of a surprise.
cards.desc: A fair, pleasing, somewhat effeminate page, of studious and intent aspect, contemplates a fish rising from a cup to look at him. It is the pictures of the mind taking form.

cards.name: Knight of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Acting on intuition or feeling. A romantic gesture, a grand gesture. Alternatively, shyness. Picking up on extrasensory vibes. Not being able to put an idea into words. Love as your motivation. Naivety, innocence. Magical thinking. The magician’s tools of the trade show faith, trust, and belief. The snake wrapped around a rose shows sensitivity and possibly hesitation.
cards.desc: Graceful, but not warlike; riding quietly, wearing a winged helmet, referring to those higher graces of the imagination which sometimes characterize this card. He too is a dreamer, but the images of the side of sense haunt him in his vision.

cards.name: Queen of Cups
cards.meaning_up: A sensitive, loving woman. A mother. A nurturer. Shy, gentle, sweet. Flexible with others, sometimes too much so. Allows for differences in others, but that can turn to enabling bad behavior. Trusting, likes to feel secure and wants to provide this for others too. In tune with her body and spirit, and also empathetic towards others’ souls. She wants to be surrounded by beauty but is not materialistic.
cards.desc: Beautiful, fair, dreamy--as one who sees visions in a cup. This is, however, only one of her aspects; she sees, but she also acts, and her activity feeds her dream.

cards.name: King of Cups
cards.meaning_up: A soft gentle man, can be wishy-washy or easily swayed by others. A loving father, a devoted husband. Family is very important to him, more than material success or professional achievement. Uncomfortable with authority, he would rather be a friend than a master. May have a very open-minded view of the world and of relationships, to the point where there is not much stability.
cards.desc: He holds a short sceptre in his left hand and a great cup in his right; his throne is set upon the sea; on one side a ship is riding and on the other a dolphin is leaping. The implicit is that the Sign of the Cup naturally refers to water, which appears in all the court cards.

cards.name: Ace of Cups
cards.meaning_up: The blossom of a new feeling. Seeing your emotions from a new angle. Letting in new friendships and connections. Opening up your heart. Becoming more flexible. Becoming more generous in giving of yourself to others. Accessing your inner intuition and inner peace. A more flowing ease coming into your life. The yin-yang is a representation of a natural balance.
cards.desc: The waters are beneath, and thereon are water-lilies; the hand issues from the cloud, holding in its palm the cup, from which four streams are pouring; a dove, bearing in its bill a cross-marked Host, descends to place the Wafer in the Cup; the dew of water is falling on all sides. It is an intimation of that which may lie behind the Lesser Arcana.

cards.name: Two of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Connection. Recognition. Meeting a new, like-minded person. Healthy relationships based on equality and mutual respect. Starting a romance with someone whom you can be yourself with. Seeing how duality operates in your world and working with it. Discovering and uncovering new parts of yourself that can now flourish. A nude – honest, open, and trusting – couple move towards each other as a scene on a classical pottery vase holding blossoming roses. Finding yourself at home in an emotional environment that allows for healing and support. Allowing something small to start to grow.
cards.desc: A youth and maiden are pledging one another, and above their cups rises the Caduceus of Hermes, between the great wings of which there appears a lion's head. It is a variant of a sign which is found in a few old examples of this card. Some curious emblematical meanings are attached to it, but they do not concern us in this place.

cards.name: Three of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Finding community. Inclusion. Feeling like you’re fitting in, in a relaxed and fun environment. Friendship. Giving and receiving emotional support. Creating a family or tribe with your friends and peers. A beneficial network. Positivity. The three women are repeated to show how seeing similarities with others, instead of differences, can create a feeling of well-being. The palm trees and sun are an idyllic outdoor setting, showing that where we find joyfulness and play can also lead us to comfort and emotional security.
cards.desc: Maidens in a garden-ground with cups uplifted, as if pledging one another.

cards.name: Four of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Passivity. Expectation rather than action. Waiting for something to happen to you. Boredom. Needing to make a change in your life but resisting doing it. Waiting for something better to come along. The cobwebs on the flowers show how something good can lose its luster through inattention or neglect. Forming connections and sustaining relationships take effort. Overcoming shyness, making the first move, doing anything rather than nothing. Combatting inertia. Not settling for easy or standard issue.
cards.desc: A young man is seated under a tree and contemplates three cups set on the grass before him; an arm issuing from a cloud offers him another cup. His expression notwithstanding is one of discontent with his environment.

cards.name: Five of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Seeing the glass as half empty. Melancholy. Pessimistic. Focusing on what’s not working rather than what is. Feeling a lack, having a negative attitude. Inaction due to negativity. Feeling down in the dumps. Biting into an apple and finding a worm creates disappointment that can then diminish hope for the rest of the apples, even ones without a worm. One bad apple can spoil the whole bunch. One negative experience can grow large in impact and can spread to infect positive experiences. A warning to shake off negativity lest it exponentially grow to overtake the positive.
cards.desc: A dark, cloaked figure, looking sideways at three prone cups two others stand upright behind him; a bridge is in the background, leading to a small keep or holding. Divanatory Meanings: It is a card of loss, but something remains over; three have been taken, but two are left; it is a card of inheritance, patrimony, transmission, but not corresponding to expectations; with some interpreters it is a card of marriage, but not without bitterness or frustration. Reversed: News, alliances, affinity, consanguinity, ancestry, return, false projects

cards.name: Six of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Generosity towards others. Sweetness. Caring. Friendship, romantic, or familial love. Sexual satisfaction. An equal exchange of emotions. Two birds are shown presenting flowers to each other, as all the birds that fly above carry flowers in their beaks. Having a good heart, being loving as a general attitude in life. Good intentions. Good feelings towards all. Feeling a part of things, a connectedness to others. Family ties, nostalgia and memories.
cards.desc: Children in an old garden, their cups filled with flowers.

cards.name: Seven of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Illusion, fantasy. Seeing too many options. Feeling like there isn’t a clear path. Wishful thinking. Hopes and dreams. Seven hands are shown with seven different objects, which have seven different purposes. Not everything in life is clear-cut, different things overlap and require discernment. Self-knowledge may be needed to clear the fog, a commitment to the self may be required to allow a commitment to something else. Decision-making based on discovering what you truly want. Opening up the third eye to refine your choices.
cards.desc: Strange chalices of vision, but the images are more especially those of the fantastic spirit.

cards.name: Eight of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Feeling like you want more, or that there’s more out there for you. Working towards your personal growth and evolution. Starting out on a spiritual journey. Not being satisfied with the status quo. It can sometimes be a tough choice to leave behind ‘good enough’ in order to find ‘even better.’ The cat shown is more interested in the flying birds just out of his reach, even though there are birds on the ground within his reach. Aiming higher than you have before.
cards.desc: A man of dejected aspect is deserting the cups of his felicity, enterprise, undertaking or previous concern.

cards.name: Nine of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Wish fulfillment. Satisfaction. Being at peace emotionally. Trusting. Allowing abundance rather than controlling it. Letting magic happen in your life. Nine genie lamps are shown, granting wishes. Many of the cards leading up to this one show how we can block our own desires through negativity or a lack of clarity. Nine is about how we achieve what we want once we let go of resistance. Good things are coming, if you continue to trust, release control, and lead with the heart.
cards.desc: A goodly personage has feasted to his heart's content, and abundant refreshment of wine is on the arched counter behind him, seeming to indicate that the future is also assured. The picture offers the material side only, but there are other aspects.

cards.name: Ten of Cups
cards.meaning_up: Picture perfect. Having it all. Personal happiness and emotional stability. Being full of love. The vessels shown all contain flowers, and they all have human faces with content expressions. Integration of the self and the setting. Being comfortable. Your actions aligning with your emotional nature. The outer self reflecting a true image of the inner self.
cards.desc: Appearance of Cups in a rainbow; it is contemplated in wonder and ecstacy by a man and woman below, evidently husband and wife. His right arm is about her; his left is raised upward; she raises her right arm. The two children dancing near them have not observed the prodigy but are happy after their own manner. There is a home-scene beyond.

cards.name: Page of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Optimism. Good things coming your way. A new way to bring in finances, or to create a new relationship with finances. A new ally at work, or a job offer. A new opportunity that may start small but can grow into something meaningful. Alternatively, being immature or unwise about finances. A new attitude towards your own security, finding your way towards being more grounded. Having the view that money can be a useful tool towards happiness.
cards.desc: A youthful figure, looking intently at the pentacle which hovers over his raised hands. He moves slowly, insensible of that which is about him.

cards.name: Knight of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Taking action that builds or creates stability. Putting down roots. Being careful. Proceeding with a plan –  or hesitating. Working behind the scenes. Focused on the process. Slowly building momentum in an organic way. Laying a foundation. The underground roots nourish the external parts of a tree, allowing the leaves to spread and dance. The hand is the most functional part of the body, our greatest natural tool, but requires source energy from the rest of the body.
cards.desc: He rides a slow, enduring, heavy horse, to which his own aspect corresponds. He exhibits his symbol, but does not look therein.

cards.name: Queen of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: A grounded, centered woman. Earthy and mothering. In tune with nature. Enjoys food, beautiful objects, and materiality. Reliable and generous. Consistent, comfortable. Can be slow to change or adjust. Can be stubborn. Can be too reliant on her senses and not her logic. Has access to wisdom of plants and animals, has a healing energy. Kind.
cards.desc: The face suggests that of a dark woman, whose qualities might be summed up in the idea of greatness of soul; she has also the serious cast of intelligence; she contemplates her symbol and may see worlds therein.

cards.name: King of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: A provider. A man who enjoys being self-sufficient, as well as sustaining others. Good with his hands, very capable but can tip over into pridefulness. A man of the earth, but can get stuck. Can be resistant to change or progression. He finds safety in what he knows and may discount or belittle what he doesn’t understand. Can be dogmatic and uncompromising. Not very flexible, but provides comfort through his stability.
cards.desc: The figure calls for no special description the face is rather dark, suggesting also courage, but somewhat lethargic in tendency. The bull's head should be noted as a recurrent symbol on the throne. The sign of this suit is represented throughout as engraved or blazoned with the pentagram, typifying the correspondence of the four elements in human nature and that by which they may be governed. In many old Tarot packs this suit stood for current coin, money, deniers. I have not invented the substitution of pentacles and I have no special cause to sustain in respect of the alternative. But the consensus of divinatory meanings is on the side of some change, because the cards do not happen to deal especially with questions of money.

cards.name: Ace of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: A new way towards financial security. A new job offer, an opportunity offered in your field. A small investment that can lead to greater gains. Taking a small step towards manifesting something valuable in your life. A financial or material gift from others. Investing in yourself. Building wealth can start with just a single coin.
cards.desc: A hand--issuing, as usual, from a cloud--holds up a pentacle.

cards.name: Two of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: A balancing act. Having multiple interests and needing to give your time and energy to all. The balance between attaining goals and enjoying them. The work/life balance is about creating your life while also living it. Performing what feel like magical acts to attain your goals. The extra effort you can put into doing something you love to do. Not being able to stop working for a second, perhaps needing to reevaluate your process if that is the case. The coins balance on the tips of fingers out of sheer will.
cards.desc: A young man, in the act of dancing, has a pentacle in either hand, and they are joined by that endless cord which is like the number 8 reversed.

cards.name: Three of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Collaboration. A joint effort, working with others. Teamwork. A balanced approach to a project. Feeling valued within your group, or needing to see the value in others around you. The bees with the hive show the benefits of individuals working together for a greater purpose. The ladder symbolizes the upward trajectory of the triangular dynamic. Two forces coming together create a third energy, greater than the two would be un-joined, as shown by the clasped hands. The overlapping circles show how finding commonalities in differences may be needed.
cards.desc: A sculptor at his work in a monastery. Compare the design which illustrates the Eight of Pentacles. The apprentice or amateur therein has received his reward and is now at work in earnest.

cards.name: Four of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Clinging to stability. Feeling financially insecure. Putting safety over happiness. When the need to feel safe prevents you from exploration or discovery. Relying too much on the structures around you. Placing your faith in the real, rational, practical, material world more than in the intuitive feeling world. Seeing material wealth as validating your own worth. The four hands holding dollars face inward to each other, creating rigidity and a boxed-in shape that excludes others. Valuing profits over people. Needing to branch out and find value in non-material things.
cards.desc: A crowned figure, having a pentacle over his crown, clasps another with hands and arms; two pentacles are under his feet. He holds to that which he has.

cards.name: Five of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Feeling excluded. Seeing an inside/outside pattern in your work, environment, and relationships. Not feeling at home in the world. Wanting external growth but actually needing internal growth. Re-aligning your values away from where they used to make sense for you. Re-defining your priorities, examining material vs. spiritual abundance. A sense that you are only surviving and not thriving. The mouse dreams of diamonds but only has some crumbs of cheese amid a crumbling setting. This cheese will still feed him– this is both a benefit and a detriment. Looking for what really sustains you.
cards.desc: Two mendicants in a snow-storm pass a lighted casement.

cards.name: Six of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: An imbalance of power. Feeling like you’re giving more than you’re receiving. Ideas of fairness in an exchange. Feeling neglected, underappreciated, taken for granted. Unhappy in a work situation– deserving a raise or a promotion. There is one hand dropping coins into two waiting hands, showing how what is given may not be enough to fulfill all your needs. Or, needing to adjust your expectations about what you feel you deserve. Relying too much on someone else to support you. Needing to find a way to support yourself, or to balance the scales.
cards.desc: A person in the guise of a merchant weighs money in a pair of scales and distributes it to the needy and distressed. It is a testimony to his own success in life, as well as to his goodness of heart.

cards.name: Seven of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Growing a venture for yourself. Owning your own business. Taking care of yourself even when things are on a downswing. Keeping faith in yourself even when its not clear things are succeeding. Seeing the long game, the larger picture. Allowing things to take the time needed. A tree sprouts leaves and dollar bills, showing how taking time and effort can yield good results. The idea of growing something – growth requires light, time and nutrients. Staying positive, patient and optimistic.
cards.desc: A young man, leaning on his staff, looks intently at seven pentacles attached to a clump of greenery on his right; one would say that these were his treasures and that his heart was there.

cards.name: Eight of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Working towards a goal. Mastery of a skill. Apprenticeship. Repetition as a path towards greatness – or towards boredom. Recognizing a pattern of behavior. Committing and putting in the time. A hand places the final brick in the final pyramid, a sign of hard work, building over time, a long process. Plodding forward with intention. Running in the race not to win, but to build endurance and muscle memory. The end goal is less important than the journey towards it.
cards.desc: An artist in stone at his work, which he exhibits in the form of trophies.

cards.name: Nine of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Readiness. Ripeness. Time to harvest, to collect, to take action. Recognizing the benefits of a situation.  Taking advantage of opportunity. A sense of satisfaction. The cherries are dripping, ready to be eaten. Sensuality. Enjoyment of earthy pleasures, gorging on fresh fruit in the small window of time before they decay. The birds on the coins carry the potential of flight, as the coins rain down. The time is now.
cards.desc: A woman, with a bird upon her wrist, stands amidst a great abundance of grapevines in the garden of a manorial house. It is a wide domain, suggesting plenty in all things. Possibly it is her own possession and testifies to material well-being.

cards.name: Ten of Pentacles
cards.meaning_up: Fulfillment. Abundance. A full life. Investment. Establishing yourself and your legacy. Inheritance. Flowers intermix with dollar bills, using money to spread happiness, to ensure a future. Completion of a project or a long term goal. Reaping the pleasures of your hard work. Being charitable. Taking care of others. Generosity. Sharing with your community. Being a benefactor for someone else. Finding a benefactor, an investor.
cards.desc: A man and woman beneath an archway which gives entrance to a house and domain. They are accompanied by a child, who looks curiously at two dogs accosting an ancient personage seated in the foreground. The child's hand is on one of them.

cards.name: Page of Swords
cards.meaning_up: New ideas, thoughts, mental paradigms. Getting assistance from others to figure out a new solution to a problem. When someone opens your eyes to a different perspective. Being able to re-write a scenario. Turning over a new leaf in your personality, learning a new skill. A hand holds open a book with only one letter, the rest to be written.
cards.desc: A lithe, active figure holds a sword upright in both hands, while in the act of swift walking. He is passing over rugged land, and about his way the clouds are collocated wildly. He is alert and lithe, looking this way and that, as if an expected enemy might appear at any moment.

cards.name: Knight of Swords
cards.meaning_up: Taking action with a clear mind. Being supported by facts and logic. Allowing your thoughts to lead the way – rushing ahead. Getting ahead of yourself, jumping to conclusions. In order to take right action, balance is needed between your ideas of things and the reality of things. When this occurs, it’s like a puzzle piece fitting into place. If not, it’s more like a dagger forced into place.
cards.desc: He is riding in full course, as if scattering his enemies. In the design he is really a prototypical hero of romantic chivalry. He might almost be Galahad, whose sword is swift and sure because he is clean of heart.

cards.name: Queen of Swords
cards.meaning_up: A smart, sharp woman. Not nurturing but still supportive. Can be cold and with a cutting tongue, can be a leader and a boss. Reliable even if distant. Solitary and unemotional, good at business and logistics. Uses her words to get ahead or to tear down others. Uses her head more than her heart, a savvy businesswoman.
cards.desc: Her right hand raises the weapon vertically and the hilt rests on an arm of her royal chair the left hand is extended, the arm raised her countenance is severe but chastened; it suggests familiarity with sorrow. It does not represent mercy, and, her sword notwithstanding, she is scarcely a symbol of power.

cards.name: King of Swords
cards.meaning_up: An authoritative figure. The man in charge. Does not show his emotions or vulnerability. Someone who is emotionally unavailable or inaccessible. A wit, good with words. Understands how the worlds of finance, science, politics work – less about how internal feelings work. Someone with walls up, who enjoys eliciting fear or respect from others.
cards.desc: He sits in judgment, holding the unsheathed sign of his suit. He recalls, of course, the conventional Symbol of justice in the Trumps Major, and he may represent this virtue, but he is rather the power of life and death, in virtue of his office.

cards.name: Ace of Swords
cards.meaning_up: A new clarity. Opening up to a new way of thinking. Figuring out a solution to a problem. Using your brain, being smart about a situation. Insight. Being careful with words & calculations. Thought as a precursor to action.  Realizing some missing information. A key to making something work, perhaps an alteration of your perceptions is needed. A simple tool like a nail can create connections strong enough to build a house.
cards.desc: A hand issues from a cloud, grasping as word, the point of which is encircled by a crown.

cards.name: Two of Swords
cards.meaning_up: Indecision, a lack of clarity due to emotional pain. Being too self-defensive. When your desire to protect yourself causes you to build emotional walls. Acting out of distrust, not moving from a clear conscious. Projecting onto others. Not seeing things clearly, only seeing through the lens of your own personal issues. Myopic vision. Seeing others as enemies, not allies. The two hands with knives are interconnected – they cannot avoid hurting each other, and themselves, as long as they keep a knife in their hands. Suggests a need to retreat from drama or chaos, to re-center within yourself, to find a more loving energy.
cards.desc: A hoodwinked female figure balances two swords upon her shoulders.

cards.name: Three of Swords
cards.meaning_up: The most iconic meaning is romantic heartbreak. Betrayal. But also –scars, holding onto emotional heartache. Allowing words to harm too deeply, allowing negative thoughts to continue to cause pain in yourself. Closing your once-open heart. A need to heal the disconnect. A heartbreaking event can cause exponentially more pain when you hold onto it, letting it find a home inside and locking the door, instead of releasing it into the wild and keeping the door to the heart open. An echo of pain that remains long after. Scissors cutting the flower that still blooms shows how emotional pain is a natural part of life, and that how deeply it hurts us depends on how we respond to it.
cards.desc: Three swords piercing a heart; cloud and rain behind.

cards.name: Four of Swords
cards.meaning_up: Recognizing that there is a need for downtime, for recuperation. Healing that comes from within. A pause in order to recover, a hibernation to calm destructive thoughts. Quiet contemplation. Introspection. Meditation. Needing time away. Looking for structures that enable healing.  A hand with acupuncture needles and another with the acupuncture points as stars shows how health resides within you and simply requires you to give it a chance to flourish. Re-aligning with the natural flows of mind, body and spirit.
cards.desc: The effigy of a knight in the attitude of prayer, at full length upon his tomb.

cards.name: Five of Swords
cards.meaning_up: Discord. Attacking others due to selfish needs. Making situations worse than they need to be. Causing drama as a way to assert yourself. Conversely, choosing your battles wisely. Not every injustice needs to be righted, by you, right now. Changing your perspective to see where you have been in the wrong, where you have been the aggressor unnecessarily, perhaps to find a fairer way to relate to others. Acting against your own interests due to pride. One wolf attacks another, not understanding that they are the same. Deciding to relate to others in a kinder way.
cards.desc: A disdainful man looks after two retreating and dejected figures. Their swords lie upon the ground. He carries two others on his left shoulder, and a third sword is in his right hand, point to earth. He is the master in possession of the field.

cards.name: Six of Swords
cards.meaning_up: Transition. Can describe a dark moment, as the light on the other end might not be seen yet. An in-between moment, which can feel uncomfortable in its ambiguity. Travelling – from one place to another, from one relationship to another, from one life to another. A temporary situation. A swan, a symbol of transformation, swims from one bank to another, while butterflies, another symbol of transformation, fly in a downward formation above her. Change is inevitable and necessary but not always easy. Accepting assistance from others during this time, a need to be gentle on yourself whenever movement is required.
cards.desc: A ferryman carrying passengers in his punt to the further shore. The course is smooth, and seeing that the freight is light, it may be noted that the work is not beyond his strength.

cards.name: Seven of Swords
cards.meaning_up: A poison pen, words meant to sting. Gossip. Being sneaky. Using strategy or manipulation. Only looking out for number one – or being in a tricky situation where you need to think of yourself first. Extracting yourself from drama – or playing into the drama. Outwitting someone. Being political in your interactions. A hand tests out the sharpness of an arrow while a snake looks on. Six more arrows are ready and waiting. Words are weapons when used intentionally against another person.
cards.desc: A man in the act of carrying away five swords rapidly; the two others of the card remain stuck in the ground. A camp is close at hand.

cards.name: Eight of Swords
cards.meaning_up: Feeling trapped in a situation, and not seeing a way out. Letting other people’s actions or perspectives dominate your own way of being, rather than working from an internal strength or intuition. Frustration at a situation. Feelings of helplessness that keep you from seeing your own agency. Flies are trapped in the spider’s web, although they are not yet killed. Pessimistic thoughts, making a bad situation worse by allowing external forces to gain power over you. A need to open your eyes to see where you do have freedom to move.
cards.desc: A woman, bound and hoodwinked, with the swords of the card about her. Yet it is rather a card of temporary durance than of irretrievable bondage.

cards.name: Nine of Swords
cards.meaning_up: Anxiety. Regret. Being chained to the past by your thought patterns. Unacknowledged, unspoken fears. Burdening yourself with your thoughts, but unable to take action. Feeling tied to the past. Rumination. A need to release old habits and thoughts in order to be lighter and freer. A pile of skulls intertwines with chains and cobwebs. An emotional house cleaning is needed. Stagnation turns to despair, darkens your soul. A need to face your fears in order to become untroubled, unburdened.
cards.desc: One seated on her couch in lamentation, with the swords over her. She is as one who knows no sorrow which is like unto hers. It is a card of utter desolation.

cards.name: Ten of Swords
cards.meaning_up: The end of a cycle. Beating a dead horse. Lingering pain. Time to move on, prolonging the inevitable. Having an exaggerated response to a conflict. Bringing up old pain and suffering in order to heal from it. A healing crisis. A snake, which normally sheds his skin, is cut up into pieces by box cutters. Needing to evolve or move on, but being so resistant to transformation that drastic events have to occur to move you forward. A wake-up call. Rock bottom.
cards.desc: A prostrate figure, pierced by all the swords belonging to the card.
